DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Alliance Says Victory in Reach in 1990s
DOC.TEXT: The country's main anti-apartheid alliance said Friday it was entering 1990 with confidence that ``victory for democracy is in sight.'' The United Democratic Front and the Mass Democratic Movement, two overlapping coalitions of opposition groups, said in a New Year's message that government efforts at repression during the 1980s had failed quell black resistance. ``Despite a determined state assault on progressive people's organizations, the state of emergency (imposed in 1986) failed miserably in its desire to submit us further to the will of the minority,'' the statement said. It said 1990 would be a pivotal year, bringing the expected release of jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and the possibility of negotiations on a post-apartheid political structure. ``What we will all be doing, from both government and liberation movement sides, will determine whether South Africa goes through the path of a bloodbath or takes the high road of a less violent transition to a non-racial and democratic South Africa,'' the statement said. ``We enter the 1990s with the hope and confidence that victory for democracy in our country is in sight.'' The state-run South African Broadcasting Corp., in a year-end commentary Friday, said ``the face of South Africa has changed dramatically and irrevocably in the 1980s'' because of moves away from racial discrimination and toward limited political power-sharing. ``Ahead lies the further broadening of democracy with the extension of the principle of power sharing at all levels of government to black South Africans,'' the commentary said. How to achieve that ``in a manner fair and equitable to all is the challenge that awaits the leadership of all political constituencies in the 1990s.'' The anti-apartheid Democratic Party, which won 20 percent of the vote in white parliamentary elections in September, commended President F.W. de Klerk for his performance since the election. The Democrats' three co-leaders praised de Klerk for freeing several prominent political prisoners, reducing the duration of mandatory military service and abolishing segregated beaches. But they said de Klerk and his National Party remained wedded to the concept of racial groups as the foundation of future political system. ``We need to introduce into our society the principles of equal and equivalent franchise for all adults,'' the Democrats' leaders said. ``Anything short of a full democracy is a threat to our safe future.''
